name: MB-6891 / Basic Master Level 3 Mark 2
description: An upgraded version of the Basic Master Level 3, with built-in chinese character ROM board.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TI 88/4A. The family computer.<br> It's easy. Connect it, connect yourself."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD #5</strong></font><br><blockquote>Upgrade kit to transform a Spectrum into a Spectrum +<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the computing answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARABIC MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>In late 1988, bilingual (arab / french) versions of the TO-7/70 were sold for peanuts. These models could display latin and arabic characters. The keyboard was also bilingual, as well as the Basic !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>A discreet advert and a nice monitor.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST US AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first 1982 U.S. Advert.<br><br> Advert said <br><br>THE COMMODORE 64 COULD BE THE MICROCOMPUTER INDUSTRY'S OUTSTANDING NEW PRODUCT INTRODUCTION SINCE THE BIRTH OF THIS INDUSTRY.  (Shearson / American Express) <br><br><font color="#666666">             The value of a computer is determined by what it can do. What it can do is largely determined by its memory.<br>             The Commodore 64's basic RAM is 64K. This amount of power is unusual in a micro at any price.<br>             At $595 it is astonishing.<br>             Compared with an Apple II+, for instance, the Commodore 64 offers 33% more power and considerably les than 50% of the cost.<br>             Compared with anything else, it's even more impressive...<br><br>             If you've been waiting for the "computer revolution", consider it as having arrived...  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA 1 PIN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - SYSTEM IN SPACE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Bottoms-up tour:<br><br> - Apple III<br> - Daisy-chain of three F.D. units<br> - 5 MB Profile hard-disc unit<br> - Apple III monochrome monitor<br> - Apple Silentype Personal Printer<br> - 132 columns Apple Writer III<br> - Apple Color Plotter<br> - 9600 bauds Apple Phone Modem</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> <font color="#666666">The 8813 was built with you, the professional, in mind...<br><br> Using the 8813, one person can process what would normally require many secretaries, several bookkeepers and a great deal of time...<br><br> The 8813 slashes the professional's overhead. It's a powerful time and money-saving ally. Prices for complete system including printer start at less than $8,000.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The incredible Secam color micro-computer !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Once upon a time, the future"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Efficient companies choose professional partners"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DMS-15</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983 advert.<br><br> The DMS-15 is a DMS-3/F with a built-in 15 MB hard disk.</blockquote>
